moves.3. Nf3 Bg4: ?! I'm not sure I like this move. Maybe it's because I don't know a good reply to Ne5.
moves.4. Ne5: The last game started with a similar set up where my bishop overextended and was attacked by an aggressive knight. Looks like I didn't learn!
moves.4... Bf5 5. cxd5 cxd5 6. Nc3 Nc6: f6 just seems to be asking for trouble at this point. This doesn't seem like a very clever move either though.
moves.7. Nxc6 bxc6 8. Qa4: c6 is looking rather weak at the moment due to the lack of a b7 pawn. Development is somewhat equal at this point but white clearly has the initiative.
moves.8... Bd7 9. Bf4: He is definitely not worried about the discover attack on his queen. Maybe because all that is threatened is a pawn.
moves.9... c5 10. Qb3 cxd4: ? I'm really asking for it this game it seems. Not sure what would be a better move but this one does not seem too good. Maybe I was in trouble already.
moves.11. Nxd5: Okay I'm in trouble now. Maybe a solution is lurking somewhere, perhaps a shot at his king.
moves.11... e5: ! Denying his bishop access to d2. Even though d2 does not seem very important at the moment, it is a fundamental square for what's to come.
moves.12. Bxe5 Qa5+ 13. Kd1: At this point white does not have very many good replies but this seems to lose the quickest.
moves.13... Ba4: Pinning the queen to his king.
moves.14. Nc7+: 14. Qxa4+ Qxa4+ 15. b3 Qany 16. Nc2+ and white's position is slightly better than what happened.
moves.14... Kd7 15. Nxa8 Bxb3+:
16. axb3 Qxa1 or 16. Kc1 Qe1#

Epicuro resigned at this point and suddenly opening strategy became very important. Even though this is a blitz game it shows you can sometimes turn a game around in difficult situations and that you should not give up.
